qa_list.question: What is the maximum length of time allowable for master's degree completion and certification?
qa_list.answer: The guidelines and restrictions place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.

qa_list.question: Who should students consult with regarding their program of study and degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.

qa_list.question: What is the requirement for federal financial aid eligibility?
qa_list.answer: Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program.

qa_list.question: How many units must students enroll each semester to receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid?
qa_list.answer: Students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree program to receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible.

qa_list.question: Who should students consult with regarding billing and financial aid?
qa_list.answer: Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than-standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.

qa_list.question: What is the policy on Master's Student Statute of Limitations?
qa_list.answer: The policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations outlines guidelines and restrictions that place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.

qa_list.question: What is the standard timeframe for completing a master's program?
qa_list.answer: The standard timeframe for completing a master's program varies by program, but students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree and graduate within this timeframe.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student does not complete their degree within the standard timeframe?
qa_list.answer: If a student does not complete their degree within the standard timeframe, they may face restrictions on their eligibility for federal financial aid and may need to consult with their academic advisor or appropriate associate dean regarding program of study.

qa_list.question: What is integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs?
qa_list.answer: Integrated undergraduate and master's degree programs are programs where students can complete both their bachelor's and master's degrees in a shorter timeframe than if they were pursuing each separately.

qa_list.question: What is the status for international students who are considering completing their degree requirements early?
qa_list.answer: F-1 and J-1 students in non-immigrant status must consult with their designated advisor to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.

qa_list.question: What happens if F-1 or J-1 students anticipate longer than standard completion?
qa_list.answer: F-1 and J-1 students in non-immigrant status must consult with their designated advisor to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.

qa_list.question: What should F-1 or J-1 students do if they want to move from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification?
qa_list.answer: F-1 and J-1 students in non-immigrant status must consult with their designated advisor to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.

qa_list.question: Who should F-1 or J-1 students consult for immigration regulation compliance?
qa_list.answer: F-1 and J-1 students in non-immigrant status must consult their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE).

qa_list.question: What is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements for F-1 and J-1 students?
qa_list.answer: Their immigration status.

qa_list.question: Why do F-1 or J-1 students need to consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE)?
qa_list.answer: To ensure compliance with immigration regulations when considering early degree completion, longer than standard completion, or moving from undergraduate to graduate student classification.

qa_list.question: What is the status for international students in F-1 and J-1 non-immigrant status?
qa_list.answer: Their immigration status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements.

qa_list.question: Who are considered as F-1 or J-1 students in the text?
qa_list.answer: International students who are in non-immigrant status.

qa_list.question: What is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements for international students?
qa_list.answer: Their immigration status.

qa_list.question: What is the requirement for maintaining full-time status at MCDS?
qa_list.answer: To be considered a full-time student, a student must be registered for and complete a minimum of 36 units in every Fall and Spring semester.

qa_list.question: Is it possible to pursue the degree as a part-time student at MCDS?
qa_list.answer: No, there is no option to pursue the degree as a part-time student at present.

qa_list.question: What happens if an international student fails to maintain full-time status?
qa_list.answer: Failure to maintain full-time status will result in loss of a student visa (and, therefore, “permit of stay”).

qa_list.question: Are students with Stafford Loan required to maintain full-time status at MCDS?
qa_list.answer: Yes, all students having a Stafford Loan are required to maintain full-time status.

qa_list.question: How many remote courses can be counted towards the 36 units used to satisfy full-time enrollment at MCDS?
qa_list.answer: A student can have no more than one (1) remote course counting toward the 36 units.

qa_list.question: What is the duration of the MCDS degree program?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS degree must be completed within five (5) years from the time that the student matriculates into the program.

qa_list.question: Is there a maximum limit for completing the master’s degree at MCDS?
qa_list.answer: Yes, students will complete all requirements for the master’s degree within a maximum of seven years from original matriculation as a master’s student.

qa_list.question: What happens if a person fails to complete their master's degree within the time-to-degree limit at MCDS?
qa_list.answer: Once this time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a master’s degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.

qa_list.question: Is it possible for someone who has exceeded the time-to-degree limit at MCDS to continue their studies?
qa_list.answer: Yes, but only if they are newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.

qa_list.question: Under what circumstances can a school or college defer the lapse of a student's program?
qa_list.answer: A school or college may defer the lapse for a period commensurate with the duration of an interruption due to leave of absence, military or public service, family or parental leave, or temporary disability.

qa_list.question: Are there any formal residence requirements in this program?
qa_list.answer: No, there is no formal residence requirement. However, most courses are taught on campus without an option for distance education.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student enrolled in an IPR course section cannot attend all class meetings?
qa_list.answer: Students enrolled in in-person course sections (IPR) are expected to attend all class meetings in person.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum number of semesters a student can pursue their master's degree as part-time students?
qa_list.answer: Students who are pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program, as approved by their program, may appeal to their program or department for extension of the time to degree limit.

qa_list.question: What is the duration of an interruption due to temporary disability?
qa_list.answer: The duration of an interruption due to temporary disability commensurate with the period of that interruption.

qa_list.question: How many courses in this program are taught without an option for distance education?
qa_list.answer: Most courses in the program are taught on campus without an option for distance education.

qa_list.question: What is the role of a dean (or designate) in relation to student's lapse?
qa_list.answer: The dean (or designate) provides written approval for a student's lapse upon recommendation from the relevant department.

qa_list.question: What is the role of a program or department in relation to extension of time to degree limit?
qa_list.answer: A program or department can appeal for an extension of the time to degree limit for students pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students.

qa_list.question: What is the duration of leave of absence, military or public service?
qa_list.answer: The duration of leave of absence, military or public service commensurate with the period of that interruption.

qa_list.question: What is required to receive an MCDS degree?
qa_list.answer: To receive an MCDS degree, students must have a Quality Point Average (QPA) of 3.0 and complete courses in the core curriculum, the MCDS seminar, electives, and capstone project.

qa_list.question: What is included in the common MCDS core?
qa_list.answer: The common MCDS core consists of five courses completed by all students in their first two semesters. This includes eight core and concentration courses, two 12-unit seminar courses, and two 12-unit capstone courses.

qa_list.question: What are the three areas for choosing a concentration?
qa_list.answer: The three areas for choosing a concentration are Analytics, Systems, or Human-Centered Data Science. All students must complete at least one of these concentrations consisting of three courses.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum number of units required to maintain full-time enrollment status?
qa_list.answer: To maintain full-time enrollment status, a student must enroll in a minimum of 36 course units per semester.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum number of units that can be taken without permission from an academic advisor?
qa_list.answer: A student may not take more than 60 units per semester, without permission from their academic advisor.

qa_list.question: Is it mandatory for students to maintain full-time enrollment status in their final semester?
qa_list.answer: Yes, all students must maintain full-time enrollment status (minimum of 36 units) in their final semester.

qa_list.question: What is the course that all MCDS students are expected to pass by the end of their first semester?
qa_list.answer: All MCDS students are expected to pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course by the end of their first semester.

qa_list.question: What is required for a student to pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course?
qa_list.answer: Each MCDS student must pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course with a grade of 'B' or better.

qa_list.question: What are the two timing options for completing the degree program?
qa_list.answer: The degree consists of two timing options based on the length of time the student spends working on the degree. The student chooses their timing at the start of the degree program (for visa requirements). Changes in timing are possible with the approval of the Director of the degree program and successful visa extension application with CMU’s Office of International Education.

qa_list.question: What is common among all degree options?
qa_list.answer: All degree options consist of the same amount of coursework.

qa_list.question: What are the two options for completing a degree in this program?
qa_list.answer: The two options for completing a degree in this program are Professional Preparation Track and Research Preparation Track.

qa_list.question: How long does it take to complete the Professional Preparation Track?
qa_list.answer: The Professional Preparation Track is a 16-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study. Each semester consists of a minimum of 48 units of study.

qa_list.question: How many units are required in each semester for the Professional Preparation Track?
qa_list.answer: Each semester in the Professional Preparation Track consists of a minimum of 48 units of study.

qa_list.question: When do students graduate from this program?
qa_list.answer: Students typically graduate in December after completing their 16-month degree consisting of Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study.

qa_list.question: What is the duration of the Research Preparation Track?
qa_list.answer: The Research Preparation Track is a 20-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and a second year of Fall and Spring study.

qa_list.question: How many units are required in each semester for the Research Preparation Track?
qa_list.answer: Each semester in the Research Preparation Track consists of a minimum of 36 units of study.

qa_list.question: Why is this timing designed for students interested in extending their time at CMU?
qa_list.answer: This timing is designed for students interested in extending their time at CMU for developing applied research skills in preparation for further graduate study or research-oriented employment.

qa_list.question: What is the difference between the two options regarding the total cost of tuition?
qa_list.answer: The per-semester course load is lower, but the total cost is higher since four semesters of tuition are paid for in this timing.

qa_list.question: What is the duration of a typical student's study period under the Professional Preparation Track?
qa_list.answer: A typical student's study period under the Professional Preparation Track is 16 months, consisting of Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study.

qa_list.question: What is the total number of units required for MCDS students to complete their graduate study?
qa_list.answer: MCDS students must complete 144 units.

qa_list.question: How many common core courses are there in the MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: There are four common core courses: Machine Learning, Cloud Computing, Interactive Data Science, and Data Science Seminar.

qa_list.question: What is the requirement for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students to choose an area of concentration in MCDS curriculum?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete at least one area of concentration which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems or Human-Centered Data Science.

qa_list.question: What are the three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take?
qa_list.answer: The three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take are 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.

qa_list.question: What are the learning outcomes of MCDS Program?
qa_list.answer: The learning outcomes of MCDS Program include designing, implementing, and evaluating analytic algorithms on sample datasets; explaining how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets; designing and executing experimental data collection and presenting resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations; applying and customizing analytics, systems, and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives; identifying tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems, and/or human-centered); survey, interpreting, and comparatively criticizing state of the art research talks and papers with emphasis on constructive improvements; organizing, executing, reporting on, and presenting a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.

qa_list.question: What are the additional learning outcomes for students electing to complete the Analytics concentration?
qa_list.answer: Students electing to complete the Analytics concentration will also learn to design, implement and evaluate a software system and machine-learning model on real world datasets at real world scale; analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains and survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.

qa_list.question: What are the additional learning outcomes for students electing to complete the Systems concentration?
qa_list.answer: Students electing to complete the Systems concentration will also learn to analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains; survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.

qa_list.question: What are the three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take?
qa_list.answer: The three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take are 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of MCDS Program FAQ?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of MCDS Program FAQ is to provide a detailed list of courses satisfying each concentration.

qa_list.question: How many Capstone courses do all MCDS students complete?
qa_list.answer: All MCDS students complete three Capstone courses: 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.

qa_list.question: What are the learning outcomes of MCDS Program?
qa_list.answer: The learning outcomes of MCDS Program include designing, implementing, and evaluating analytic algorithms on sample datasets; explaining how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets; designing and executing experimental data collection and presenting resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations; applying and customizing analytics, systems, and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives; identifying tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems, and/or human-centered); survey, interpreting, and comparatively criticizing state of the art research talks and papers with emphasis on constructive improvements; organizing, executing, reporting on, and presenting a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.

qa_list.question: What are the additional learning outcomes for students electing to complete the Analytics concentration?
qa_list.answer: Students electing to complete the Analytics concentration will also learn to design, implement and evaluate a software system and machine-learning model on real world datasets at real world scale; analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains and survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.

qa_list.question: What are the additional learning outcomes for students electing to complete the Systems concentration?
qa_list.answer: Students electing to complete the Systems concentration will also learn to analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains; survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.

qa_list.question: What are the three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take?
qa_list.answer: The three Capstone courses that all MCDS students must take are 11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar, 11-635 - Capstone Research, and 11-632 - Data Science Capstone.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of MCDS Program FAQ?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of MCDS Program FAQ is to provide a detailed list of courses satisfying each concentration.

qa_list.question: What is the main focus of the Human-Centered Data Science (HCDS) concentration?
qa_list.answer: The HCDS concentration emphasizes on providing experimental evidence for design decisions and anticipating and avert structural and/or implementation problems with systems design, especially with scaling and tail distributions.

qa_list.question: What are the key skills that students will learn in their coursework?
qa_list.answer: Students will learn to design, implement and evaluate a user experience prototype for clear understanding of data science solutions. They will also apply social and behavioral research methods to data science problems to understand the human aspects of data collection and analysis.

qa_list.question: What is the Capstone project in HCDS?
qa_list.answer: The capstone project consists of students working individually or in a team on a project that integrates their educational experience. It can be a CMU research project, an industry-sponsored project, or occasionally students define their own topics with the MCDS faculty.

qa_list.question: What are elective courses for HCDS?
qa_list.answer: Electives can be any graduate level course (numbered 600 or above) in the School of Computer Science. Students use these to enhance study in an area of interest or explore new areas.

qa_list.question: What are undergraduate courses for HCDS?
qa_list.answer: Undergraduate courses can be any course numbered 100-599 offered by the School of Computer Science.

qa_list.question: What are elective courses in the School of Computer Science?
qa_list.answer: Electives can be any graduate level course (numbered 600 or above) in the School of Computer Science. Students use their elective courses to enhance study in an area of interest or to explore new areas of interest.

qa_list.question: What are undergraduate courses?
qa_list.answer: Undergraduate courses (numbered less than or equal to 599) may be taken pass/fail or for credit but do not count toward the 144 units of eligible study: The course and course grade will appear on the student’s transcript, and the course grade will factor as part of the student’s QPA.

qa_list.question: How many units are required for a graduate level course in School of Computer Science?
qa_list.answer: No specific number is mentioned. It's stated that elective courses can be any graduate level course (numbered 600 or above).

qa_list.question: What happens if a student takes an undergraduate course pass/fail?
qa_list.answer: The course and course grade will appear on the student’s transcript, and the course grade will factor as part of the student’s QPA.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of elective courses in School of Computer Science?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of elective courses in School of Computer Science is to enhance study in an area of interest or to explore new areas of interest.

qa_list.question: Can a student take undergraduate courses for credit?
qa_list.answer: Yes, students can take undergraduate courses for credit. However, these courses do not count toward the 144 units of eligible study.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum level number for graduate level course in School of Computer Science?
qa_list.answer: The maximum level number for a graduate level course in School of Computer Science is 600 or above.

qa_list.question: How many units are required to pass an undergraduate course taken as pass/fail?
qa_list.answer: No specific number is mentioned. It's stated that the course and course grade will appear on the student’s transcript, and the course grade will factor as part of the student’s QPA.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student takes an undergraduate course for credit?
qa_list.answer: The course and course grade will appear on the student’s transcript, and the course grade will factor as part of the student’s QPA.

qa_list.question: What is an independent study course?
qa_list.answer: An independent study course allows students to cover a particular area of interest when no formal course is available in that subject area. It often offers the opportunity for research directly with a faculty member and are considered electives.

qa_list.question: Who must approve an independent study course?
qa_list.answer: Each independent study course must be advised and approved by at least one faculty member. Agreement to supervise the course is voluntary on the part of the faculty member.

qa_list.question: What are the steps a student needs to take before starting an independent study?
qa_list.answer: 1) The student must request approval from their academic advisor and complete a proposal before the first day of classes in a given semester. 2) Enter into an agreement with the independent study supervisor that includes course expectations, including deliverables. 3) Secure the 'Independent Study Contract Form' from the MCDS administrator. 4) Complete the form, provide a brief description of the work to be done, including deliverables and how they will be graded. 5) Secure signatures of both the student and the supervisor. Return the form to the MCDS administrator in order to obtain approval for the independent study from the Director.

qa_list.question: When must a student submit an independent study contract?
qa_list.answer: Independent study contracts must be submitted no later than on the last day of the first week of classes in a given semester.

qa_list.question: What is double counting courses?
qa_list.answer: No course may be used to complete two MCDS degree requirements, nor may a course satisfy requirements in two degree programs.

qa_list.question: Can a student take a course outside of the School of Computer Science for their MCDS degree?
qa_list.answer: No, no course may be used to complete two MCDS degree requirements, nor may a course satisfy requirements in two degree programs.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of independent study courses for students who are interested in continuing to a Ph.D. degree?
qa_list.answer: Independent study courses offer an opportunity for research directly with a faculty member, which can be beneficial for students pursuing a Ph.D.

qa_list.question: What is the role of independent study supervisors in CMU?
qa_list.answer: Independent study supervisors are faculty members who agree to advise and guide students taking an independent study course.

qa_list.question: How do students find a faculty member willing to be their independent study supervisor?
qa_list.answer: Students must negotiate the terms and conditions of the independent study with pertinent faculty members who will be supervising the course.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student fails to submit an independent study contract by the deadline?
qa_list.answer: If a student fails to submit an independent study contract by the deadline, they may not be able to take the course that semester.

qa_list.question: When should independent study contracts be submitted?
qa_list.answer: Independent study contracts must be submitted no later than on the last day of the first week of classes in a given semester.

qa_list.question: Can a course satisfy requirements in two degree programs?
qa_list.answer: No, a course may not be used to complete two MCDS degree requirements nor may it satisfy requirements in two degree programs.

qa_list.question: Are elective courses from other Schools at Carnegie Mellon allowed for SCS CMU students?
qa_list.answer: Yes, elective courses in other Schools at Carnegie Mellon may be taken with prior permission of the Director.

qa_list.question: How are grades graded in all courses offered by the SCS CMU?
qa_list.answer: All courses offered by the SCS CMU are graded on the 4.3 grading standard http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/Grades.html.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum grade requirement for MCDS students?
qa_list.answer: MCDS students must obtain a B- or better grade in all courses which count towards core requirements and maintain a 3.0 overall average each semester to remain in good standing.

qa_list.question: What happens if an MCDS student does not maintain a 3.0 overall average?
qa_list.answer: If an MCDS student does not maintain a 3.0 overall average, they will be placed on academic probation and may face other consequences.

qa_list.question: What is the grading standard for courses offered by SCS CMU?
qa_list.answer: The grading standard for courses offered by SCS CMU is 4.3, which can be found at http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/Grades.html.

qa_list.question: Can a course satisfy requirements in two degree programs?
qa_list.answer: No, a course may not be used to complete two MCDS degree requirements nor may it satisfy requirements in two degree programs.

qa_list.question: When should independent study contracts be submitted?
qa_list.answer: Independent study contracts must be submitted no later than on the last day of the first week of classes in a given semester.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum QPA a student must maintain to remain in good standing with the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: A cumulative QPA of 3.0

qa_list.question: Can courses taken pass/fail count towards the MCDS degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: No, only courses that receive a letter grade can count towards the MCDS degree.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student's cumulative QPA drops below 2.6 during any given semester?
qa_list.answer: The student may be put on academic probation or dismissed from the program, depending on their standing and previous infractions.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of an academic progress review in the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: To monitor individual student progress towards graduation regarding the fulfillment of curricular requirements, course grades, and academic integrity.

qa_list.question: Who can provide an official letter of enrollment for a CMU student?
qa_list.answer: Enrollment Services is the only University office that can provide such a letter.

qa_list.question: How can a student request enrollment verification from Enrollment Services at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Through The HUB website: https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/student-records/verifications/

qa_list.question: What happens if a student fails to meet the academic standards and policies established by Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The student may be dismissed from the program.

qa_list.question: If a student is put on Academic Probation, what are they required to do in the following semester?
qa_list.answer: They must enroll in courses as advised by their academic advisor and maintain a cumulative QPA of 3.0.

qa_list.question: What happens if an MCDS student receives an Academic Integrity Violation (AIV) deemed an infraction by the MCDS committee?
qa_list.answer: The AIV will be noted in their letter of review and may result in further academic actions.

qa_list.question: What happens when a student's overall QPA drops below 3.0 during any given semester?
qa_list.answer: The student will be placed on academic probation for the following semester and required to enroll in courses as advised by the academic advisor, improve his/her grades to no less than an overall 3.0 QPA in the following semester, and meet any other goal set by the advisor during that period (e.g., fulfilling a core course requirement).

qa_list.question: What happens if a student's cumulative QPA drops below 2.6?
qa_list.answer: The student will be considered at risk of being unable to complete the program and will be considered for dismissal. He/she will be required to meet with the program director to discuss his/her situation.

qa_list.question: What are the consequences if a student fails to improve their grades after academic probation?
qa_list.answer: If a student's cumulative QPA remains below 3.0 in the following semester, they will be considered for dismissal from the program.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum QPA required to remain in good standing with the MCDS committee?
qa_list.answer: Students must maintain a cumulative QPA of 3.0 to remain in good standing with the program.

qa_list.question: Who decides whether or not a student is likely to complete the program if their cumulative QPA drops below 2.6?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS program committee ascertains that the student is likely to complete the program.

qa_list.question: What happens during an academic probation period?
qa_list.answer: During this time, students are required to enroll in courses as advised by their academic advisors and improve their grades to no less than a 3.0 QPA.

qa_list.question: What is the role of an academic advisor during probation?
qa_list.answer: Their role includes advising students on which courses they should enroll in and setting goals for them to achieve, such as fulfilling a core course requirement.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student fails to meet the goals set by their academic advisor during probation?
qa_list.answer: If a student fails to improve his/her grades or meet any other goal set by the advisor, they will be considered for dismissal from the program.

qa_list.question: What is an Academic Integrity Violation (AIV) deemed as?
qa_list.answer: An infraction

qa_list.question: What happens if a student is put on academic probation and fails to meet the remedial requirements set by their advisor in the following semester?
qa_list.answer: The student will be dismissed from the program.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they realize that one of the situations mentioned applies to them?
qa_list.answer: They are encouraged to meet with their academic advisor to discuss a plan to mitigate the situation.

qa_list.question: When can an instructor award a grade of 'I' (incomplete) for a course?
qa_list.answer: An instructor may award a grade of 'I' when a student has been unable to complete the work of a course, but only if the work completed up to that date is of passing quality.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student fails to complete the remaining work for an incomplete grade?
qa_list.answer: The instructor must specify the requirements for completing the work and designate a default letter grade in case the student fails to complete the remaining work.

qa_list.question: What are the grounds for dismissal from the program according to the MCDS committee?
qa_list.answer: The grounds for dismissal include committing two Academic Integrity Violations deemed infractions by the MCDS committee, committing an Academic Integrity Violation where the violation is deemed sufficiently egregious as determined by the MCDS program committee, and infringing a University Policy.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they find themselves struggling in the program?
qa_list.answer: They are encouraged to communicate early and often with their academic advisor for the best chances of success.

qa_list.question: Why is it important for Carnegie Mellon University students to complete a course during an academic semester?
qa_list.answer: It is expected that students will complete a course during the academic semester in which the course was taken, as incomplete grades provide no undue advantage over other students.

qa_list.question: What should be of passing quality when an instructor awards an 'I' grade?
qa_list.answer: The work completed up to that date must be of passing quality for the student to receive an incomplete grade.

qa_list.question: What is an 'I' grade in this context?
qa_list.answer: An 'I' grade stands for Incomplete, which means that a student has not completed all the required course work.

qa_list.question: When must students complete their remaining work if they fail to do so by the end of an academic semester?
qa_list.answer: If a student fails to complete the required course work by the end of an academic semester, they must finish it sooner as per the instructor's requirement.

qa_list.question: What is the default letter grade if a student fails to complete their remaining work?
qa_list.answer: The default letter grade designated by the instructor in case of incomplete course work is specified when awarding an 'I' grade.

qa_list.question: How long do students have to finish their required course work after receiving an 'I' grade?
qa_list.answer: Students are given until the end of the following academic semester or sooner if instructed by the teacher to complete their remaining work.

qa_list.question: What is the significance of the number 20 in this context?
qa_list.answer: The number 20 likely represents the total amount of course work that a student needs to complete before receiving an 'I' grade, or it could be used for other purposes as per the instructor's discretion.

qa_list.question: What does the phrase 'designate a default letter grade' mean?
qa_list.answer: The term means that when an 'I' grade is awarded, the teacher specifies what letter grade will be given if the student fails to complete their remaining work.

qa_list.question: What does it mean for a course work to be completed?
qa_list.answer: Course work is considered completed when all assigned tasks and assignments have been finished by the student according to the instructor's requirements.

qa_list.question: How can an 'I' grade affect a student's academic standing or future opportunities?
qa_list.answer: An 'I' grade may negatively impact a student's GPA and could potentially limit their access to certain programs, scholarships, or job opportunities.

qa_list.question: What is the role of an instructor in awarding an 'I' grade?
qa_list.answer: The instructor plays a crucial role by specifying the requirements for completing course work and designating a default letter grade if the student fails to complete their remaining tasks.

qa_list.question: What should the instructor do if they have not recorded the permanent course grade by the last day of the examination period?
qa_list.answer: The Registrar will automatically assign a default grade.

qa_list.question: If further work has not been completed after one semester and a default grade is rendered, what happens to that grade?
qa_list.answer: The default grade becomes the grade of record.

qa_list.question: What should an instructor do if they believe a grade was assigned in error?
qa_list.answer: They should discuss the matter with the course instructor and provide evidence that the grade issued was incorrect.

qa_list.question: What should a student do if they believe their grade was issued in error?
qa_list.answer: The student should contact the program administrator to process a Change of Grade Form.

qa_list.question: Who is generally considered as the final authority for assigning course grades?
qa_list.answer: The instructor is generally considered as the final authority for a course grade.

qa_list.question: What should be done if a student leaves to pursue another academic program before completing MCDS degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: If the requirements for the MCDS degree have not been completed when a student leaves, the degree will not be awarded.

qa_list.question: Does completion of the MCDS degree guarantee admission into any doctoral degree program at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: No, completion of the MCDS degree does not insure admittance to any doctoral degree program.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about intellectual property policy in the MCDS degree program?
qa_list.answer: Students should refer to Carnegie Mellon University's policy on intellectual property: http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/IntellProp.html

qa_list.question: Are there any teaching requirements for students in the MCDS degree program?
qa_list.answer: No, there are no required teaching requirements.

qa_list.question: Do non-native English speakers have to meet specific language proficiency requirements?
qa_list.answer: No, there are no required language proficiency requirements. However, they can take advantage of support functions provided by the Intercultural Communication Center (ICC) and the Global Communication Center (GCC).

qa_list.question: What should a student do if their course instructor has not assigned a grade?
qa_list.answer: The student should notify the course instructor for the completion of a Missing Grade Form.

qa_list.question: What is considered a serious violation in the university?
qa_list.answer: Any form of cheating or plagiarism

qa_list.question: Why must students understand and follow only permitted forms of collaboration as defined by their instructor?
qa_list.answer: Because it is a serious violation of student ethics.

qa_list.question: What happens if you use the work of others without proper citation?
qa_list.answer: You must not use the work of others without proper citation

qa_list.question: Can students use resources, including other persons, except as authorized by their course or project?
qa_list.answer: No, they cannot use resources, including other persons, except as authorized by the course or project for which they are submitting the work.

qa_list.question: What happens if you fail to abide by these rules in the university?
qa_list.answer: Failure to abide by these rules can result in your permanent separation from the University without refund of money paid.

qa_list.question: Is it acceptable or commonplace for students to use resources, including other persons, except as authorized by their course or project?
qa_list.answer: No, such conduct is not accepted or commonplace in the university.

qa_list.question: What does the MCDS program strive to produce graduates with?
qa_list.answer: The highest standards of academic integrity

qa_list.question: What happens if a student commits an Academic Integrity Violation for the second time in the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: If a student commits a second violation, the expected penalty is dismissal from the graduate program.

qa_list.question: Where can students review the University Policy on Academic Integrity?
qa_list.answer: Students can review the policy at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the University Policy on Academic Integrity?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the policy is to provide definitions and expectations around academic integrity, including what constitutes cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.

qa_list.question: What are the consequences for violating the University Policy on Academic Integrity?
qa_list.answer: The policy outlines procedures for investigating, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing academic integrity violations. The severity of these consequences can vary depending on the nature of the offense.

qa_list.question: What is the process for reviewing the University’s Academic Disciplinary Actions procedures?
qa_list.answer: The policy recommends that students review the procedure outlining the investigation, reporting, adjudication, and appeal processes for academic integrity violations.

qa_list.question: What are the circumstances under which a final grade can be appealed?
qa_list.answer: Final grades may only be changed in exceptional circumstances such as manifest error (e.g., clear errors).

qa_list.question: Who has the discretion to approve changes to final grades?
qa_list.answer: The instructor and department, unit or program have the discretion to approve changes to final grades.

qa_list.question: What is the appeal process for academic actions at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The policy outlines an appeal process that includes reviewing, reporting, adjudicating, and appealing academic integrity violations.

qa_list.question: How are grading decisions made by instructors at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Grading is a matter of sound discretion for the instructor. Final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade.

qa_list.question: What resources does Carnegie Mellon University provide to help students understand academic integrity?
qa_list.answer: The policy provides definitions and expectations around academic integrity, as well as procedures for investigating and adjudicating violations. The Word also offers additional information on the topic.

qa_list.question: What is the URL of the University Policy on Academic Integrity?
qa_list.answer: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html

doc_text:
of the semester in which they have completed their degree requirements.
Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations
www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of- limitations.html
See the above link regarding guidelines and restrictions which place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
Additional Guidance for Students
Program of study. Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Financial aid and student account Students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree to graduate within the standard timeframe for their program of study. Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program. To receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible, students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree level. (See separate guidance regarding integrated degree completion.) Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than- standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.
International students Immigration status for students in F-1 and J-1 non-immigrant status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements. Therefore, F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE) to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.
12


3.2 Full-time Status All MCDS students are expected to enroll full-time (at present, there is no option to pursue the degree as a part-time student). To be considered a full-time student, a student must be registered for, and complete, a minimum of 36 units in every Fall and Spring semester. All international students are required by US Federal law to maintain full-time status. Students can have no more than one (1) remote course counting toward the 36 units used to satisfy full-time enrollment. Failure to maintain full-time status will result in loss of a student visa (and, therefore, “permit of stay”). All students having a Stafford Loan are required to maintain full-time status.
3.3 MCDS Degree Enrollment Process and Related Information
3.3.1 Duration of the degree program
The MCDS degree must be completed within five (5) years from the time that the student matriculates into the program.
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of- limitations.html
As outlined in the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations (see link above), students will complete all requirements for the master’s degree within a maximum of seven years from original matriculation as a master’s student, or less if required by a more restrictive department, school or college policy. Once this time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a master’s degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.
Under extraordinary circumstances, such as leave of absence, military or public service, family or parental leave, or temporary disability, a school or college may, upon the relevant department's recommendation and with the written approval of the dean (or designate), defer the lapse for a period commensurate with the duration of that interruption. Students who are pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program, as approved by their program, may also appeal to their program or department for extension of the time to degree limit.
3.3.2 Residency requirements
There is no formal residence requirement. However, most courses in the program are taught on campus without an option for distance education. Students enrolled in in- person course sections (IPR) are expected to attend all class meetings in person.
3.3.3 Degree Certification: Course requirements and related policies/protocols
13



In order to receive the MCDS degree, students must have a Quality Point Average (QPA) of 3.0. Completion of the degree is based on completing courses in the core curriculum, the MCDS seminar, electives and capstone project.
The capstone project consists of students working at CMU on a research project, or on an industry-sponsored project.
The student must complete 144 eligible units of study. This includes eight core and concentration courses, two 12-unit seminar courses and two 12-unit capstone courses. All students complete a common MCDS core in their first two semesters, consisting of five courses. All students must also complete at least one concentration, consisting of three courses in one of three areas: Analytics, Systems, or Human-Centered Data Science. The remaining elective course can be any course with number 600 or above chosen from the SCS course catalog. Any additional non-prerequisite units taken beyond the 144 units are also considered electives.
To maintain full-time enrollment status, a student must enroll in a minimum of 36 course units per semester. A student may not take more than 60 units per semester, without permission from their academic advisor. Students must maintain full-time enrollment status (minimum of 36 units) in their final semester.
3.3.4 Prerequisite Core Course
All MCDS students are expected to pass the 11-637 Foundations of Computational Data Science course by the end of their first semester. Each student must pass 11-637 with a grade of “B” or better.
3.3.5 Plan of study
The degree consists of two timing options based on the length of time the student spends working on the degree. The student chooses their timing at the start of the degree program (for visa requirements). Changes in timing are possible with the approval of the Director of the degree program and successful visa extension application with CMU’s Office of International Education. Note that all degree options consist of the same amount of coursework:
Professional Preparation Track – a 16-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and Fall semester of study. Each semester consists of a minimum of 48 units of study. This timing is typical for most students. The student graduates in December.
Research Preparation Track – a 20-month degree consisting of study for Fall and Spring semesters, a summer internship, and a second year of Fall and Spring study. Each semester consists of a minimum of 36 units of study. This timing is designed for students interested in extending their time at CMU for developing applied research skills in preparation for further graduate study or research- oriented employment. Note that the per-semester course load is lower, but the total cost is higher since four semesters of tuition are paid. This timing is also 14


recommended for students interested in pursuing a PhD after graduation. The student graduates in May.
3.3.6.1 MCDS Curriculum
All MCDS students must complete 144 units of graduate study which satisfy the following curriculum:
11-637 - Foundations of Computational Data Science  Four (4) additional MCDS Core Courses (10-601 Introduction to Machine Learning; 05-839 Interactive Data Science; 15-619 Cloud Computing; 11-631 Data Science Seminar; 48 units)
Three courses (3) from one area of concentration curriculum (36 units)  Three (3) MCDS Capstone courses (11-634, 11-635 and 11-632) (36 units)  One (1) Elective: any graduate level course 600 and above in the School of Computer Science (12 units)
3.3.6.2 Common MCDS Core Courses
All MCDS students are required to complete four common core courses in their first two semesters:
10-601 - Machine Learning  15-619 - Cloud Computing  05-839 - Interactive Data Science  11-631 - Data Science Seminar
3.3.6.3 Areas of Concentration
In addition to the common MCDS core, all students must complete at least one area of concentration, which consists of three courses in Analytics, Systems, or Human- Centered Data Science. Students consult with their academic advisor and choose one or more areas of concentration during their first semester, in preparation for enrolling in Spring classes.
Analytics concentration:
o One (1) Machine Learning course o One (1) Software Systems course o One (1) big data course
Systems concentration:
o 15-513 Introduction to Computer Systems (elective, prerequisite for many
advanced Systems courses)
o Three (3) systems project courses  Human-Centered Data Science concentration:
o One (1) Methods course o Two (2) HCI courses
15


A detailed list of courses satisfying each concentration is contained in the MCDS Program FAQ.
3.3.6.4 MCDS Capstone Courses
All MCDS students complete three Capstone courses:  11-634 - Capstone Planning Seminar (12 units)  11-635 - Capstone Research (12 units)  11-632 - Data Science Capstone (12 units)
MCDS Program Learning Outcomes
Design, implement and evaluate the use of analytic algorithms on sample datasets.
Explain how a machine-learning model is developed for and evaluated on real world datasets.
Design and execute experimental data collection and present resulting analyses using appropriate user experience (UX) techniques including interactive data visualizations.
Apply and customize analytics, systems and human-centered data science techniques to application-specific data science requirements and objectives. Identify tradeoffs among data science techniques (analytics, systems and/or human-centered) and contrast design alternatives, within the context of specific data science application domains.

Survey, interpret and comparatively criticize state of the art research talks and papers, with emphasis on constructive improvements.
Organize, execute, report on, and present a real world data science project in collaboration with other researchers/programmers.
Depending on the concentration, additional learning outcomes are emphasized:
Analytics. Students electing to complete the Analytics concentration will also learn to:
Design, implement and evaluate a software system and machine-learning model on real world datasets at real world scale.
Analyze and document data science requirements in different application domains and survey as well as critique state of the art solutions for those requirements.
Systems. Students electing to complete the Systems concentration will also learn to:
16



Implement and evaluate complex, scalable data science systems, with emphasis on providing experimental evidence for design decisions.
Anticipate and avert structural and/or implementation problems with systems design, especially with scaling and tail distributions.
HCDS. Students electing to complete the Human-Centered Data Science (HCDS) concentration will also learn to:
Design, implement and evaluate a user experience prototype to allow for clear understanding of data science solutions.
Apply social and behavioral research methods to data science problems to understand the human aspects of data collection and analysis.
Throughout their coursework, students will take introductory courses on all those topics, practice them in advanced courses and seminars and demonstrate all learned skills in their Capstone project and internship. Students are encouraged to choose elective courses in the curriculum according to their professional goals and mastery of the main subjects.
3.3.10 Capstone project
The capstone project consists of students working in a team or individually on a project. The capstone project integrates the educational experience of the student. A capstone project is typically a CMU research project, or an industry sponsored project; occasionally students define capstone topics through communication with the faculty. Students interested in defining their own capstone topics should discuss with the MCDS faculty as early as possible. The capstone project is a great opportunity for a student (or student team) to “show off” their unique skills and accomplishments. Capstone projects have been instrumental in the hiring decisions for several employers.
3.3.11 Elective courses
Electives can be any graduate level course (numbered 600 or above) in the School of Computer Science. Students use their elective courses to enhance study in an area of interest or to explore new areas of interest.
3.3.12 Undergraduate courses
Undergraduate courses are taken to address an area of weakness in the student’s prior preparation. Undergraduate courses (numbered less than or equal to 599) may be taken pass/fail or for credit but do not count toward the 144 units of eligible study: The course and course grade will appear on the student’s transcript, and the course grade will factor as part of the student’s QPA.
17


3.3.13 Independent study course
Independent study courses allow students to cover study of a particular area of interest, and are used when no formal course is available in a given subject area. Students who are interested in continuing to a Ph.D. degree often enroll in Independent Study, since it offers the opportunity to perform research directly with a faculty member. Independent study courses are considered electives.
Each independent study course must be advised and approved by at least one faculty member. Agreement to supervise an independent study course is purely voluntary on the part of the faculty member. It is the duty of the student, therefore, to negotiate the terms and conditions of the independent study with the pertinent faculty members of CMU who will be supervising the study. These individuals are referred to as “independent study supervisors.” Once the student finds someone who agrees to supervise such a course, he/she must:
1. Students wishing to take an independent study must request approval from their academic advisor and complete proposal before the first day of classes in a given semester:
2. Enter into an agreement with the independent study supervisor that includes course expectations, including deliverables.
3. Secure the “Independent Study Contract Form” from the MCDS administrator. 4. Complete the form, provide a brief description of the work to be done, including deliverables and how they will be graded.
5. Secure signatures of both the student and the supervisor. Return the form to the MCDS administrator in order to obtain approval for the independent study from the Director.
Independent study contracts must be submitted no later than on the last day of the first week of classes in a given semester.
3.3.14 Double counting courses
No course may be used to complete two MCDS degree requirements, nor may a course satisfy requirements in two degree programs.
3.3.15 Courses outside of the School of Computer Science
Elective courses in other Schools at Carnegie Mellon may be taken with prior permission of the Director.
3.3.16 Grades
All courses offered by the SCS CMU are graded on the 4.3 grading standard http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/Grades.html. MCDS students must maintain a 3.0 overall average each semester to remain in good standing. A student must obtain a B- or better grade in all courses, which count towards core requirements. If a student
18


receives a C- or better, that course may count as an elective towards the degree requirements. All courses must receive a letter grade; courses taken pass/fail do not count towards the MCDS degree.
Enrollment Services is the only University office that can provide an official letter of enrollment, official transcript and enrollment verification. Enrollment verification can be requested online through The HUB at: https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/student- records/verifications/
3.3.17 Student Review, Academic Probation and Academic Actions
The MCDS program conducts an academic progress review at the conclusion of each semester in order to monitor individual student progress towards graduation regarding the fulfillment of curricular requirements, course grades, and academic integrity. Should a student’s effort fall below the acceptable level of academic performance and/or fail to meet standards and policies established by Carnegie Mellon University, the student may be dismissed from the program.
Infractions
After each academic progress review, each student will receive a letter indicating the result of the review and their standing in the program. If applicable, the letter will also note the following infractions by the student in the given semester:
Cumulative QPA is below 3.0, resulting in the student being put on Academic Probation (see below)
Cumulative QPA is below 2.6, resulting in academic probation or possible dismissal (see below)
Academic Integrity Violation (AIV) deemed an infraction by the MCDS committee (see 3.7.2)
Minimum QPA and Academic Probation
Students must maintain a cumulative QPA of 3.0 to remain in good standing with the program. Should a student’s overall QPA drop below 3.0 during any given semester, he/she will be placed on academic probation for the following semester. In probation cases, the student will be required to
enroll in courses as advised by the academic advisor, 
improve his/her grades to no less than an overall 3.0 QPA in the following semester, and
meet any other goal set by the advisor during that period (e.g., fulfilling a core course requirement).
If a student’s cumulative QPA drops below 2.6, the student will be considered at risk of being unable to complete the program and will be considered for dismissal. He/she will be required to meet the program director to discuss his/her situation. Only if, after that meeting, the MCDS program committee ascertains that the student is likely to complete
19


the remaining program requirements in the allotted time, the student will be allowed to continue his/her studies in MCDS, and dismissed otherwise. If the student is allowed to continue their studies, they will be placed on academic probation for the following semester and is subject to the requirements above.
Dismissal
A student may be dismissed from the program for any of the following cases:





If the student has been put on academic probation and failed to meet the remedial requirements set by the advisor in the following semester, or committed an Academic Integrity Violation deemed an infraction by the MCDS committee while on academic probation If the student has a cumulative QPA of 2.6 or lower and the MCDS program committee does not ascertain that the student is likely to complete the remaining program requirements in the allotted time If the student has committed two Academic Integrity Violation deemed infractions by the MCDS committee (see 3.7.2) If the student has committed an Academic Integrity Violation infraction where the violation is deemed to be sufficiently egregious as determined by the MCDS program committee If the student has been found to infringe a University Policy, where such infringement is deemed grounds for dismissal
Students who realize that one of these situations may apply to them are strongly encouraged to meet with the academic advisor to discuss a plan to mitigate the situation. Students who find they are struggling in the program will have the best chances of success if they communicate early and often with the academic advisor.
3.3.18 Incomplete grades
Carnegie Mellon University students are expected to complete a course during the academic semester in which the course was taken. However, if the instructor agrees, a grade of “I” (incomplete) may be given when a student has been unable to complete the work of a course. However, the work completed up to that date must be of passing quality and the grade of incomplete provides no undue advantage to that student over other students.
By awarding an “I” grade, an instructor must specify the requirements for the completion of the work and designate a default letter grade in the event that the student fails to complete the remaining work.
Students must complete the required course work by no later than the end of the following academic semester or sooner if required by the instructor.
20


The instructor must record the permanent course grade by the last day of the examination period of the following semester, or the Registrar will automatically assign the default grade.
If further work has not been completed after one semester and a default grade is rendered, the default grade will become the grade of record.
3.3.19 Change of grades and missing grades
If a grade has been assigned in error, it can be changed to a different permanent grade. The procedure for changing a grade is as follows:  Discuss the matter with the course instructor; provide evidence that the grade issued


was not the grade earned. If the instructor agrees, the student should contact the program administrator to process a Change of Grade Form in order to correct the grade that was issued in error. Generally, the instructor is the final authority for a course grade. If a grade has not been assigned, please notify the course instructor for the completion of a Missing Grade Form.
3.3.20 Qualifying examinations and procedures (or equivalent)
None required.
3.3.21 Thesis/dissertation
None required.
3.3.22 On transfer to another program
If the requirements for the MCDS degree have not been completed when a student leaves to pursue another academic program, the degree will not be awarded. Completion of the MCDS degree does not guarantee admission into any doctoral degree program at Carnegie Mellon University. The courses that will be completed as part of the MCDS may serve to enhance one’s application to these programs but will in no way insure admittance.
3.3.23 Intellectual property policy
The MCDS degree program adheres to Carnegie Mellon University policy on intellectual property: http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/IntellProp.html
3.3.24 Teaching requirements
None required. However, students are encouraged to apply for teaching assistant positions in courses where they have excelled.
3.3.25 Language proficiency requirements
None required. However, non-native English speakers are encouraged to take advantage of the various support functions provided by the Intercultural Communication Center (ICC) and the Global Communication Center (GCC).
21


3.3.26 Academic Integrity and Policies on Plagiarism and Cheating
The university considers any form of cheating or plagiarism to be a serious violation of student ethics. The student is required to understand and rigorously follow only the permitted forms of collaboration as defined by the instructor in every class. The work you submit must be your own, unless you have clearly attributed it to others. You must not use the work of others without proper citation. And, you must not use resources, including other persons, except as authorized by the course or project for which you are submitting the work. Such conduct might be accepted or commonplace elsewhere, but it is not here. Be careful. Be warned. Failure to abide by these rules, even just once, can result in your permanent separation from the University without refund of money paid. Note that the policy requires the student to be informed and understand the academic integrity rules for every assignment or exam in a course.
The MCDS program strives to produce graduates with the highest standards of academic integrity. Academic Integrity Violations are taken very seriously and the MCDS program has a zero tolerance policy for multiple Academic Integrity Violations. A single violation is grounds for dismissal from the graduate program if deemed sufficiently egregious as determined by the MCDS program committee. If a student commits a second violation, the expected penalty is dismissal from the graduate program (see also academic progress review at section 3.3.17).
Please review the University Policy on Academic Integrity: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/academic-integrity.html The policy includes the University expectations around academic integrity and provides definitions of cheating, plagiarism, and unauthorized assistance.
A review of the University’s Academic Disciplinary Actions procedures https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/academic-discipline/index.html is also recommended. These procedures outline the process for investigating, reporting, and adjudicating violations of the University Policy on Academic Integrity. The procedures also outline the appeal process.
3.3.27 Process for Appealing Final Grades
https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/academic/appeal-of-grades-and-academic-actions.html
Final grades will be changed only in exceptional circumstances and only with the approval of the instructor and the department, unit or program. Grading is a matter of sound discretion of the instructor and final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade. The following circumstances are the unusual exceptions that may warrant a grade appeal: (a) the final grade assigned for a course is based on manifest error (e.g. a clear error suc
